Crime_Name: Immigration and Refugee Protection Act Violation
Legal_Issue: Whether the Refugee Appeal Division (RAD) erred in applying the reasonableness standard to the Refugee Protection Division's (RPD) credibility findings
Application_Facts: Applicant claimed domestic violence as persecution in Georgia; RPD found her not credible post-2005 due to inconsistencies
Decision_Outcome: No reviewable error by RAD; application for judicial review dismissed
Claimant_Status: Applicant seeking refugee status in Canada
Assessment_Factor: Credibility of applicant, consistency of testimony
Procedural_Issue: Judicial review based on alleged error in review standard applied by RAD
Credibility_Assessment: RPD found applicant not credible post-2005; RAD upheld finding and conducted independent assessment
Evidence_Used: Inconsistencies in applicant's testimony regarding domestic violence
Application_Basis: Fear of persecution due to domestic violence
Governing_Rule: RAD must conduct independent assessment but owes deference when RPD has particular advantage or credibility is determinative
Outcome: Claim rejected due to credibility issues
Decisional_Body: Refugee Protection Division (RPD), Refugee Appeal Division (RAD)
Harm_Assessment: Domestic violence alleged as form of persecution
Cause_Description: Applicant sought refugee status alleging domestic violence in Georgia; claim rejected over credibility
Evidence_Handling: RAD reviewed RPD's credibility findings and conducted its own assessment
Evidence_Assessment: RAD assessed credibility independently while applying reasonableness standard
Decision_Rationale: No reviewable error; RAD appropriately applied reasonableness and conducted independent analysis
